item.title: Elon Musk Says Twitter Has Had Massive Revenue Drop as Layoffs Begin
item.description: Elon Musk tweeted that Twitter has had a large drop in revenue due to activist groups pressuring advertisers, as the social-media company notified about half its staff that they were being let go.

item.title: For Chip Makers, the Flip from Shortage to Glut Intensifies
item.description: After sharp growth during Covid, semiconductor executives now put hiring on pause and cut costs amid high inventory.

item.title: Layoffs Hit Tech as Amazon, Lyft Warn of Downturn
item.description: The outlook for tech industry jobs worsened with ride-hailing company Lyft and payments company Stripe both announcing major layoffs and Amazon saying it will freeze corporate hiring for months.

item.title: Saudi Arabia to Build Electric Vehicles With Apple Supplier Foxconn
item.description: The kingdom’s Public Investment Fund is partnering with the biggest assembler of Apple iPhones.

item.title: Vonage Will Pay $100 Million to Settle FTC Allegations of Trapping Consumers in Subscriptions
item.description: Agreement with Ericsson subsidiary represents largest penalty in FTC enforcement push to stop companies from creating obstacles to consumer cancellations,

item.title: Reported Ransomware Incidents, Costs Soared in 2021, Treasury Says
item.description: Bank reports show the number and value of ransomware-related transactions more than doubled last year from 2020, though the true numbers are thought to be far higher.

item.title: Why Elon Musk's Quest to Revive Twitter Is Likely to Fail
item.description: Musk’s strategy at Twitter might work at a startup, but Twitter is a mature company in an extremely competitive market, with little prospects for growth.

item.title: What Happened When One School Took Smartphones Away From the Kids
item.description: Nearly two months after the ban, students are getting used to life without social media and the drama of group texts—even if not all of them love it.

item.title: The Unraveling of Trevor Milton: 'Trouble for Troublemakers'
item.description: As investors and General Motors bet on Trevor Milton’s vision, the short sellers at Hindenburg Research revealed that the company he founded, Nikola, wasn’t all that it seemed. The allegation that Nikola rolled its truck down a hill for a promotional video made Hindenburg’s report a sensation. In this episode, we’ll hear how Trevor Milton, investors and the U.S. government responded to the report—and how its authors ended up in a game of Spy vs. Spy with shadowy private investigators.

item.title: When Will Flying Taxis Get Off the Ground?
item.description: The CEO of Boeing-backed Wisk Aero on what it will take to build the market, and what is the loudest part of the trip.

item.title: Meta's Nick Clegg to New Twitter Owner Elon Musk: 'Welcome to the Club'
item.description: The president of global affairs at Meta Platforms argues that the Facebook parent’s recent business struggles are overblown.

item.title: The Company That Lost $800 Billion
item.description: Intelligent failures in business are based on small bets. Meta bet the farm.

item.title: The Weird-Looking, Fuel-Efficient Planes You Could Be Flying In One Day
item.description: Engineers are exploring radical new designs for commercial planes that would use less energy and lower emissions. But will passengers be willing to board them?

item.title: Paul Allen's Quest for Sunken Warships
item.description: The late Microsoft co-founder made it his mission to locate some of World War II’s most famous wrecks, using cutting-edge technology.

item.title: TuSimple Probed by FBI, SEC Over Its Ties to a Chinese Startup
item.description: Government authorities are investigating whether the U.S. self-driving trucking company defrauded investors by financing and transferring technology to China-backed Hydron.

item.title: Why Google Plays Down Its Ad-Tech Business but Is Determined to Keep It
item.description: Facing antitrust scrutiny, the tech giant has resisted breaking up its ad-tech operations, which feed into Google’s larger ad business.

item.title: The Indonesian Village Making Viral YouTube Videos
item.description: In a country with some of the highest user rates in the world, residents of one village are turning content creation into a local industry.

item.title: Microsoft's Struggles Enter the Metaverse
item.description: Problems plagued development of its HoloLens augmented reality headset, a ring-shaped computer worn like a crown that displays digital information on attached goggles. “We had the opportunity to own this market,” said a former director on the team.

item.title: Two Men Rode a Decadelong Tech Wave in China---Only One Is Staying
item.description: Derek Li and Rick Chang both benefited from China’s tech boom. When the atmosphere changed, each had to make a decision.
